note: . . concerning you: see note to 11.139–40.
title: Glorious Odysseus has been here before

note: the family tree included in the note to 20.215–41.
title: son of Laomedon: on Priam’s father, see note to 21.441–57, and cf

container-title: and you two . . . false oaths: the ancient scholar Aristarchus took this as a reference to Hades and Persephone
note: alternatively, it may be a reference to the Furies (cf. 19.259–60).
title: ruling from Mount Ida: Zeus is invoked here as a local deity. In the Iliad he often observes the Trojan War from Mount Ida, south-east of Troy
the island | Cranaë: the location of this island was debated in antiquity; the name probably just means ‘rocky island’

note: note to 11.750–1.
title: Amphimachus: Amphimachus’ father, one of the two Moliones, is Poseidon’s son, cf

note: see Calydon on Map 1.
title: in all Pleuron and in | steep Calydon: in western Greece

note: . . arrogant Deïphobus: cf. 11.159–66.
title: since I shattered the one I was carrying before

note: . . the Ephyri or the great-hearted Phlegyans: Ares was traditionally thought to come from Thrace; the Ephyri and the Phlegyans probably lived in Thessaly, in northern Greece.
title: with him goes his dear son Panic: personified Panic is described as Ares’ son also in Hesiod’s Theogony 934. 301–2 and these two leave Thrace

note: . insulted me: Menelaus killed Hyperenor, brother of Euphorbus, at 14.516–19.
. . to an immortal mother: on Achilles’ horses, see note to 16.149–54.
title: Mentes, leader of the Cicones: features only here. 75–8 you are now running after what you cannot reach

note: . . their prey and prize: cf. 16.656–65.
title: now you have abandoned Sarpedon
we could bring Sarpedon himself into Ilium: Glaucus is unaware that the gods have carried Sarpedon’s body to Lycia

note: cf. 24.62), and brought gifts (cf. 18.84–5).
title: . had given to his father: the gods attended the marriage of Peleus and Thetis
the son of Cronus poured a thick mist: the gods repeatedly spread or dispel mist, but only here do we get a full account of the mist’s onset, continuation (366–77
Hippothous, the illustrious son of Lethus the Pelasgian: on the Pelasgian allies of Troy

note: . . the mist and the fighting: cf. note to 17.269.
title: and you could not have said

note: . . is stretched right through: a detailed description of leather tanning.
title: As when a man gives the hide of a great ox

note: grandson: on Achilles’ horses, see note to 16.149–54.
title: But the horses of Aeacus

note: 644–50 for they themselves . . . the battle was all made plain: cf. note to 17.269.
